Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
Almost in firing range, Captain...
Understood. Where's our Belle at? She should be here by now.
@BATTLE
Captain, we have a situation.
I noticed during the battle. The Belle isn't too keen on communication, is she?
She's been yelling at us, Captain. On behalf of most of the new crew - we just want her to try and speak English around us. It's the only way we'll understand her.
I'll chat with her.
Fieramosca?
Cosa vuoi?

Fields.MenuText: Are we going to have a problem? I need you to communicate with the crew in a language they understand.
You need to realize that not everyone speaks Italian. The new crew members would appreciate it if you'd use English every now and then.
I'd appreciate it if you could at least speak some conversational English. Otherwise, we're going to have some issues.

Fields.DialogueText: Una minaccia? If it'll get you off my back, then I'll do it.
Fine. But don't expect me to learn a whole language just to please you.
The issue I'm seeing is a crew that can't understand a simple language. If it makes them stop crying, I'll dumb it down for them.
Are you going to keep up this attitude with your superior? We're on the same side, Fieramosca.
You got what you wanted, now I'd like some privacy... partire.
Use the lingua franca for operational communications. That's all I ask.
Lingua franca? Grr...
... You know what I mean.
She'll be along. She said she was getting over... a headache.
Did she now.
I haven't picked up her language yet, but I got the gist of it.
Mindbending. As you were.
I told you, I'm fine.
Hard to believe, Fieramosca. You're finally speaking in a language most of us understand, but you're refusing to let us know whether you have a problem.
That sounds like trouble.
Queste sciocchezze... you think I'm going to give you the chance? I can fight. I don't need your help.
Fine, so be it. Captain, you try getting through to her.
Arguing doesn't help our situation.
Neither does an inspection. I'm fine. Last thing I want is some rookies tinkering around. Too dangerous.

Fields.MenuText: No one is looking to replace you, Fieramosca. The crew just wants to make sure you're operating at full power.
I don't see what the big deal is. The crew wants you to be in top shape for the Morganas. If I were you, I'd listen to their advice.
You can trust us. We're all fighting the same enemy. No one is out to get you.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Because every time they see what's going on with me, I end up missing out on a fight. I know what I can handle.
I'm listening to their advice, Capitano. That's how I know it's cowardice!
Your concern is noted. I refuse to let the Morganas gain any leverage over us.
Don't worry. I mean it.
Okay. But sooner or later, you're going to have to let your crew see if you're okay...
@BATTLE
Rookies!? Some of us have spent our whole lives at sea!
*ALARM*
I'd be better if that maledetto alarm wasn't so piercing!
Think of it like an alarm clock. It makes a sound you want to get up and stop.
By smashing it?
I'm sure you appreciate why that wouldn't be helpful.
For you, maybe. A Bella Fantasma can sense danger from half an ocean away.
Except when she has a headache, apparently...
*ALARM*
Sono quasi a tiro, Capitano.
On my order...
@BATTLE
Nice work, everyone. We pushed the Morganas back.
Per adesso... who knows what's next.
Come on, that's no way to celebrate a victory. Every win should be taken in stride. Another step.
Inutile. Wars are won swiftly. We can't take our time celebrating a small victory.

Fields.MenuText: It's important to keep the crew in high spirits. We can't win if we aren't motivated.
I agree with you there, but we can't have a downtrodden crew. That won't win any battles.
No shame in appreciating the small things, Fieramosca. You could try opening up sometime...

Fields.DialogueText: We won't win if there's a lack of focus. They can't forget that we're fighting.
Hmm... I guess that makes sense.
Ha! Io non la penso così. I'll pass, Capitano.
You sure know how to kill a mood.
I just don't believe that we need all of this... bombast.
A little celebration is bombastic to you?
Ora che ci penso... no. It is false bombast, a pale imitation of the real thing. Once the war is won, we must have a triumph worthy of the name.
Might be a long war.
Così sia. It might be a long triumph. For now, give me a strawberry sherbet frappe and call it a day.
Wouldn't that be nice?
That was a request, Capitano. I want one.
Oh, good grief.
We're running out of options.
We can hold our own against them. Keep up the pace.
Will do, Captain.
If we keep this up, then this will only lead to more trouble down the road for all of us.
So what do you suggest?
We ram them. Head on. Time to be creative.
Are you crazy? If we do that, you'll be out of commission. There's too much to lose.
It's your call, Capitano. Even if it's the wrong one.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not putting you and the ship at risk, Fieramosca. Stay strong. We'll overcome this.
We have to end this quickly. Otherwise, we could put everyone in danger. We're charging them at full speed.

Fields.DialogueText: If you say so...
Glad you agree with this, Capitano. It's the right move.
For now... look for an opening!

Fields.MenuText: It's not a joust, Fieramosca.

Fields.DialogueText: Spoken like a capitano whose armor was left at home.
@BATTLE
Maledetto codardo! I'd like to see you do it better!
Believe me, I'm thinking about it.
Stop this at once! I don't tolerate infighting, least of all with the ship.
I think we should talk, Captain.
About what?
The Belle, Fieroguaio.
That's not her name. Where did you come up with that name?
Already talking behind my back? That's hardly the etiquette of an officer...
Oh. Great. Glad to see you, Fieramosca. We were just about to discuss potential strategies.
That's what you were about to discuss? I'm sure. Clearly, this officer wants you to find a way to get rid of me.

Fields.MenuText: For obvious reasons, that's not going to happen. Did you really suggest such a thing?
Don't be so quick to judge, Fieramosca. Everyone isn't out to get you.
Regardless, I'd like to steer this conversation into something productive... like how to deal with the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course not! I just want to offer some insight.
We're on the same side, Fieramosca. I was going to try to have a civil discussion with our captain.
I was going to get around to that when the Belle interrupted!
Enemy Morganas inbound, Captain.
We'll deal with all of this later.
@BATTLE
Senza dubbio. You've given me something to dwell on. Stress isn't good for a headache, you know.
Neither is being sunk. You'll manage.
These battles are beyond straining. We need to start thinking of ways to improve our ability.
Well, you still won't allow the crew to give you a proper inspection. By the way...
How many times do I have to tell you? I'm healthy. If anything, it's the food.
The food? I'm not sure that I follow.
I'm a vessel that requires careful maintenance. I can't perform at my best when we have food of such poor quality.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think the food is negatively affecting us.
Higher quality food might be too expensive in the long run. We need to pay heed to our budget in times like these.
Are you sure it's the food?

Fields.DialogueText: It can, Capitano. Food gives everyone energy. If the food is poor, we won't be able to endure long on the seas.
I understand, but if we're all at less than our best because of the quality of food we're eating, won't that just prolong the war in the long run? Cost us even more money in the end?
I'm sure. My endurance depends on good food.
I'm not going to promise anything, Fieramosca, but I give you my word I'll look into the food situation.
Smart move, Capitano.
And if you were to let the crew perform an inspection, I might have more incentive to consider the possibility of better food.
... Un patto col diavolo.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Speaking of devils...
Capitano? What are you doing down here among the engines?
Well, it seemed quiet, relatively speaking, and I thought...
That's why I like it so much. Because no one bothers me down here. Until now.
Earlier one of the officers called you something...
Fieroguaio.
That was the name. Where'd it come from?
"Proud trouble." My failures. Such a cute nickname, isn't it?
Is that part of the reason why you don't want an inspection?
You could say that. They're just looking for a reason to scrap me.

Fields.MenuText: I won't let them call you by that name, Fieramosca. You're doing the best that you can.
Next time, come to me. I could have sorted this situation out long ago.
Try not to let it bother you, Fieramosca. I need you at your best.

Fields.DialogueText: Th-thank you, Capitano. I really am trying.
Now that I know I can trust you... I might.
I'm always at my best, Capitano. I can't control my circumstances.
*ALARM*
Whether you feel up to a fight or not, they're going to give us one. I need all of you out there.
Come vuoi, Capitano. I'll try.
@BATTLE
I just don't trust any of them.
Solely because of where they're from?
Someone seems to be having an interesting discussion.
It shouldn't come as a shock. Just because everyone has to play nice doesn't mean we're all friends.
I know that. And at least you don't hide your beliefs or loyalty. No one has to wonder what you think about anything. Or anyone.
Non come gli altri...

Fields.MenuText: This is the first time I've seen you this lively, Fieramosca. What's going on?
Finally getting along with the crew?
You? Unfriendly? Perish the thought.

Fields.DialogueText: Just discussing current events.
Don't jump to conclusions, Capitano. I grew weary of lurking around... and thought I might find some entertainment.
Of course I'm not unfriendly! Don't be dense.
We were just discussing some of the other Belles.
Morganas en route!
I'm beginning to understand, whether I want to or not.
@BATTLE
Watch how you give that warning, Lieutenant!
Which ones?
Well, I happened to mention Surcouf--
Grr...
*ALARM*
We've been spotted, Capitano.
Well, we wouldn't want this to be too easy, right?
@BATTLE
Capitano, we've been fighting together for a little while.
It doesn't seem like it's been that long, but you're right. We've been through our share of battles.
I must say, I think you could do better.
Come again?
I can't help but notice how reserved you are during all of our confrontations with the enemy.
A calm mind is invaluable in a battle, especially for a leader. Anything less would be cause for worry for the crew.
We don't need a cool head. We need risk takers. We need a commanding officer who's willing to do whatever it takes to win, no matter the cost!
Think you'll be able to rise up when the time comes?

Fields.MenuText: I should be asking you the same thing, Fieramosca. Are you ready to defend your country, no matter the cost?
Of course I will. Are you worried?
There's a time and place for every tactic. We have to be cautious every now and then.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I am. I just hope you can keep up, Capitano.
I'm worried about a lack of incentive, Capitano. But I think if you take some insight from me, maybe we'll stand a chance.
You can't be cautious all time. If you're too slow, then it could cost you.
Of course, Fieramosca. You take your role in this war seriously. As long as that's the case, I can work with you.
... Grazie. I think.
Captain, there's a problem.
With the Belle. Let me hear it.
Yes, actually. She's costing us an arm and a leg.
Belles can be expensive. We simply have to pay the price we must for their help.
I understand that. But Fieramosca is costing too much.

Fields.MenuText: How much is she costing us, exactly?
We'll find a way to work with what we have. No point in making things difficult.
I'm sure you're exaggerating.

Fields.DialogueText: An order of magnitude more than similar vessels. I mentioned Surcouf to her and she threw a wrench at me.
Things are already difficult, Captain. Fieramosca is an expensive Belle. Her repairs are becoming too much of a hassle.
The fact that she sustains more damage than most Belles during every fight should be of major concern. She's getting worn down.
So what do you suggest we do?
Well, that brings me to her personal food budget.
Yes, I've seen the manifests. I've thought about paring it down until her performance improves. It's just a matter of doing so without her noticing.
You're the captain. Order her.
Capitano! You know I can't leave my quarters before I've had my Cerignola olives! Where are they!?
Why do you need those?
If I don't get my sodium, I'll be dead on my feet during the battle!
Can't you get those from any old olives?
That just makes her more stubborn.
*sigh* Look, I'm trying. I've gotten her to budge on some things, but it's a damned minefield. She--
Regular ones aren't big enough!
Oh, for the love of...
*ALARM*
I was going to tell you. The Morganas disrupted the supply chain. Your shipment will be a week late at least.
Grr... I'm giving them a piece of my mind!
Did they really?
No, it was a weather delay. It's all in how you frame it.
@BATTLE
Why have we stopped moving toward the Morganas? They're going to get away if we don't pursue them!
You've taken too many hits recently, Fieramosca. We need to assess the damage before we jump back into a brawl.
How can you even think about letting them go? We should strike now, while they're on the back foot. That one's limping!
Intel's spotty in this region, Captain. We're in a bad situation; if it's a feint...
Do you really want to give the Morganas an advantage? Sei spaventato?
Your parameters aren't equal to the risk.
Senza senso! We can't fail. I won't allow it.

Fields.MenuText: Everyone just calm down. We stick to our guns on this. Let's take care of the Morganas quickly. We can argue later.
We're not taking any chances. Stay on the defensive and wait for the right moment to attack.
Fieramosca is tough. I trust her. Keep pushing forward.

Fields.DialogueText: Sounds good to me.
I hope you don't regret that, Capitano.
Finally. Someone who understands. You heard the capitano.
Understood, Captain.
I hope we live through this...
@BATTLE
Looks like our allies underestimated themselves. The Morganas are already withdrawing.
We'll keep our distance. There's no telling what they've got up their sleeves.
What's wrong?
It just seems too quiet. Like the calm before...
There it is.
I'm guessing you allowed this? It certainly wasn't my fault.
Huh? Allowed what?
That last battle was nothing. But according to some of the superiors, that last mission exposed a salient in our strategy.
Slow down, Fieramosca. What's going on?
They want to restrict me in battle. They're all saying that I'm too reckless.
As long as I'm in charge, and as long as you're in working order, I'll do my best to see that you remain in the fight. But only as long as that's the case.
I hope you can keep your word on that. I feel watched in port and at sea, by friend and foe...

Fields.MenuText: The best thing to do right now is to be careful. We don't want to put you in a bad predicament.
The crew will listen to me. They'll understand that you're doing your best.
Just keep a cool head. This will all settle sooner or later.

Fields.DialogueText: As much as I dislike caution... you may be right, Capitano.
I hope they do. A lot of them don't seem to like me.
It better be sooner.
*ALARM*
Don't worry. I'm with you, Fieramosca.
@BATTLE
You let me handle my machinery! I'm not letting anybody else muck things up.
They're working on old intelligence regarding your capabilities. If you'd just submit to an inspection-
At least someone is.
Got a minute, Capitano?
It's unusual for you to stop by my quarters. What's on your mind?
Nothing... really... I just thought a talk could pass the time.
Okay... sure. What do you want to talk about?
How do you win?
How do you win... what?
How do you win a war?

Fields.MenuText: You win by outsmarting the enemy. You think of strategies that are beyond their understanding.
Throw everything you have at your enemy. Rush them until they can't get back up.
There's no easy way to win. No matter the enemy, you have to win the war of attrition.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly. You take risks. Push everything as far as possible, then strike.
I would agree. A shame the enemy seem to get back up time and time again.
Waiting isn't really my specialty, Capitano. You give them an opportunity to strike if you wait.
So, that's what you really think?
Something the matter, Fieramosca?
Not at all. This has been... enlightening.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Good. We've got a fight on our hands.
It's nice to just unwind... no trouble, no drama, no interruptions...
It's time for a plan of action, Captain.
So much for a rest.
Am I interrupting? I can come back another time.
No, no, no. Come on in. You want to talk about a plan of action?
We can't continue to endanger our crew.
Our crew is in danger? Let me guess... Fieramosca is still not letting you go forward with inspecting the vessel?
That's correct. I figured that you would have a better chance than me.
What do you want me to do?
It doesn't matter to me as long as you convince her to let us take a look.

Fields.MenuText: I'll talk to her. But I'm not making any promises.
Do you think she'll listen to me?
If it'll calm everyone down, I'll convince her.

Fields.DialogueText: That's all I ask, Captain. Good luck.
She likes you... better than the rest of us, at least.
It will. Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
What a thing to think about before a battle...
@BATTLE
It's got all of us on edge, especially when that alarm goes off. I swear some days I can hear stuff rattling that shouldn't.
Morganas are inbound. Looks like they haven't noticed us yet.
Excellent. Maintain a steady course. We'll take them by surprise, then hold our ground.
Then what?
Hm?
We catch them off guard, then stand still? Sounds like a waste of an opportunity.
You have a better idea?
Hit and run. If we keep moving after we hit them, we could circle them like a vulture and keep hitting them from all sides.
I don't think you're fast enough for that.
What, because I'm too large? Spit it out! Will we hit and run or won't we?

Fields.MenuText: You heard the Belle. Let's charge.
We'll keep it safe. If it goes south, then we'll use your plan as a contingency.
Smart thinking. I like it.

Fields.DialogueText: Here's to hoping no one screws this up for us.
I don't like that, but you listened. That means something.
That's how you win, Capitano.
Steady as she goes. Fieramosca's on the job.
@BATTLE
Now watch as I show everyone how it's done.
She's picked up some initiative all of a sudden.
I should hope so. I had her olive ration doubled.
I think it's time we talk about something crucial.
Crucial, huh? Vai avanti.
One of the officers came by...
I'm going to take a wild guess. He was upset that he couldn't get permission to check to see if I'm okay, so he sent you after me.
You're observant. I guess you're still hesitant to let us inspect you?
I changed my mind. Do whatever you want.

Fields.MenuText: Just like that? No fighting back?
That was... easier than I expected.
Perfect. Glad you understand.

Fields.DialogueText: Nessuna. You've worn me down.
Expected a fight? Or that I'd chuck some chairs and tables at you?
Just get on with it. I don't like having people rooting around me.
Why were you so nervous about it beforehand?
It's... complicated.
I should know. It could affect the war effort.
Not really in the mood right now, Capitano.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Would the promise of a strawberry sherbet frappe afterward take the edge off?
... Forse un pochino.
I heard the good news, Captain.
That quickly? Word spreads fast.
Fieramosca came to me herself and apologized.

Fields.MenuText: Fieramosca apologized? Are you sure?
We're talking about the same Fieramosca, correct?
She did seem concerned about the crew earlier. Maybe she's sorry for that?

Fields.DialogueText: She absolutely did. I think she's opening up to the crew a bit more. Took her long enough.
We are talking about the same Fieramosca. She's changing. I think.
Beats me, but it's getting easier to work with her. That's all that matters.
Morganas. Everyone. Let's move.
Sounds like we have a job to do.
Now she's the first one to spot the enemy? She really does care...
@BATTLE
Good hustle, Fieramosca. You've earned that frappe.
Hmph. I suppose so.
All right, now I know something's wrong.
I'll say. Compared to her usual demeanor, she's been downright pleasant.
That doesn't unnerve you?
Oh, I'm unnerved, Captain. But it's a good kind of unnerved.
Maintenance went well.
Glad to hear it. But you seem to think otherwise.
I've had my share of life experiences, Capitano...
Is that so?
I'm... not... this is hard to say...
I'm a problem. An expensive, reckless, and unorthodox problem.

Fields.MenuText: You've got some kinks in your armor, sure. But weakness can sometimes give way to strength.
None of us are perfect, Fieramosca. You need to understand that.
You're afraid that you won't remain cost effective?

Fields.DialogueText: I guess... but I have so many. It's always an uphill battle.
True, but not all of us are equal. That includes us Belles.
I passed that point a long time ago.
When does high maintenance become too high?
Fieramosca...
*ALARM*
I have to go. Morganas.
@BATTLE
You don't have to answer that. It'd be Spain all over again.
What's she talking about?
I knew this would happen. You're going to put me in drydock, aren't you? Is that it?
I didn't say that.
I don't believe you.
Okay, what's all this ruckus about?
He thinks I'm a coward.
I didn't say that. I'm just saying that, after looking over the vessel, Fieramosca might want to take things easy for a while.

Fields.MenuText: He's just worried about you, Fieramosca.
Fieramosca knows her limits.
Can't we all just get along?

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't seem like it... but I suppose it might be a possibility.
That's right. I know when enough is enough.
I wish we could.
Abbastanza. I sense our enemy on the prowl.
All right, so maybe her senses are up to snuff. That's just the tip of the iceberg.
I'll talk to her.
@BATTLE
Look, I'm not saying she's falling apart, but--
Giusto. And if you know what's good for you, you won't.
But if you'd been left even a week longer-
Capitano. You've been at the helm of this conflict for a while...
You could say that.
And I want to say that I was wrong about you.

Fields.MenuText: You were wrong about me?
I take it that you had doubts concerning my ability when we first met?
I have a feeling I'm about to hear something mean.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so. I hope I'm wrong about a lot of things.
You haven't the slightest idea, Capitano.
What makes you say that? I'm not mean.
I thought you'd do your best to keep me subdued. That you'd be afraid to take chances.
I'm afraid to take chances when I can't make an educated guess. Now that we've had a proper look at your capabilities, I can. That's all I needed to know.
Right. You just wanted to understand me. And that... means a lot.
*ALARM*
I imagine keeping you in sweets helps as well.
More than you know.
@BATTLE
What do you mean?
Exactly what I said. I want to say that's the case.
Capitano...
Look to port. Do my eyes deceive me, or...?
... No, that's mist forming. Call the crew to general quarters - and good eye.
@BATTLE
What was that back there?
What's going on?
That one screwed up. I had an opinion about it.
I have a feeling it's more than that.
Well, what can you expect from the French?

Fields.MenuText: I don't like where this is heading.
They're fine... I suppose? I don't have an opinion or problem with them.
You do realize a fair few of our crew are French, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: All I did was tell him not to be so lackadaisical, and he snapped at me.
You're more trusting than I am. I don't trust them or their Belles.
Hmph. I thought I smelled cigarettes.
You're well aware that we have a multinational crew, Fieramosca. How did you think he would react?
I suppose I wouldn't appreciate him saying anything derogatory about Italy...
You better apologize. Quickly, please.
What was what!?
You know what I'm talking about! I won't have you launching my torpedoes all negligent like some maledetto francese!
Listen, Belle, I'm French, so watch your mouth!
Grr... Fine! Run from your better!
Bene allora. I'll try to mean it.
I talked with some of the French crew.
How'd it go?
About as good as you can imagine. But they seem less angry than they did before.
Good. I need this crew working together.
It's nonsense...
What is?
That I had to apologize. Shouldn't I have the right to say what I please? I can't help it if they--

Fields.MenuText: If it compromises our ability to work together, then it's better to keep those opinions to yourself. Maybe reexamine them.
You do have freedom on this vessel, but I expect us to treat one another with kindness.
If it ends in a potential fight, I'd rather all of us try to focus on the objective instead.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm going to need to drink on this.
I'll try to do better. I just wish they'd... grr.
War comes first. I understand that. I just wish they'd do some focusing of their own.
Thanks, Capitano.
Of course, Fieramosca. Now let's all get to stations. We're drawing close to the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Sì, Capitano. My crew won't have anything to fear from those witches.
Including the French.
Well, that goes without saying.
Good.
Not that I wanted to say it.
What was that? Something about not wanting your usual Cerignola olives?
Eep! Niente, Capitano!
Hard to believe...
What's hard to believe?
That I haven't been decommissioned yet. I guess it's a good thing.

Fields.MenuText: I remember you were afraid of that. Why do you keep dreading that? It can't be good for your mental health.
As long as you're with me, that's not going to happen.
You can trust the crew. You are too strong, too invaluable, to lose.

Fields.DialogueText: Like I said before, I've failed so many operations.
Veramente? That's... I mean, I...
I-I don't know what to say...
I think what I'm trying to say is... thank you.
For what?
For putting up with me... I know I'm rough around the edges...
Once upon a time you wouldn't have even admitted that. I know you're committed to getting stronger.
@BATTLE
They've been watching me for years, Capitano. Ever since we intervened in Spain's little domestic dispute.
I... didn't do so well. It wasn't my fault, I swear. I can't help how I'm built. Now that I'm awake... I don't want it to be too late. I don't want someone to look at me and decide I'm worthless.
We all have challenges we need to overcome. You don't let yours stop you. Neither will I.
Then, Capitano... don't hold back! Don't ever hold back. Because I'll be watching you too. I want to see how strong you really are.
*ALARM*
Let's find out.
I'm glad that you've decided to spend some more time with me.
Really? Why?
You were so reclusive before. It was hard to even talk to you.
But you've softened up. I'm glad to actually sit and have a chat with you every now and then.
I guess I'm doing this out of selfishness. I just want to know that there's someone out there who'll fight for me if I fail.

Fields.MenuText: I'll keep an eye out for you, Fieramosca. You can trust me.
As long as you do the same, it's a deal.
Someone has to. Where would you be without me?.

Fields.DialogueText: I know that now, Capitano. I appreciate it.
Sure thing... but don't drag me down with you, okay?
I sincerely hope you're joking...
You're nowhere as bad as you think you are, Fieramosca. In fact, when you're considering the needs of others, you can be almost pleasant.
Hush, you.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Was that on purpose?
Now really, Capitano. Even I wouldn't abuse my alarm so.
This food still stinks.
You're back to the food? It's fine.
You want the most out of me, don't you? Then I need better food.
We can't afford your fancy diet all the time, Fieramosca. How many times do I have to tell you?
And what was with that last battle? You played it too safe.

Fields.MenuText: Of course I did. We needed to strike at the right moment.

Fields.DialogueText: But then again, we won. And the crew did do a decent job.
Don't push me.

Fields.MenuText: You're a handful, you know that?
Where would we be without you, Fieramosca?

Fields.DialogueText: And I dare say I'm in good hands.
At the bottom of the Tyrrhenian, no doubt.
Hmph. I still think you could have created your own opportunity rather than wait around for one.

Fields.MenuText: You don't need to throw yourself into the thick of it every time.

Fields.DialogueText: But I'm a submarine! I'm supposed to show up where they least expect me!

Fields.MenuText: You're welcome.

Fields.DialogueText: Hey! Don't impugn my skills. I could have scattered them myself.
Bien.
... The French ones, too.
Don't... don't go there without me. You're not allowed.
Aye-aye.
